awd_titl_txt: Integrating and Scaffolding Research into Undergraduate STEM Curricula: Probing Faculty, Student, Disciplinary, and Institutional Pathways to Transformational Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Participation in undergraduate research provides well-documented benefits to students, including high academic achievement, educational persistence, and significant gains in knowledge and skills.  Yet equity gaps in participating in research persist.  To address this shortcoming, this project will assist faculty in departments of biology, chemistry, physics, and psychology in designing and implementing coordinated four-year curricula to provide all students with equitable access to the benefits of undergraduate research.   Two departments at each of twelve institutions will be competitively selected for their interest in comprehensive research-infused curricular reform. Each department involved in the project will be assisted by expert consultants who will maintain sustained communication to oversee and guide the curricular transformation process.  Research will be conducted to characterize the factors that enable students to participate and persist in an inquiry-driven curriculum and to identify the strategies that support faculty, departments, and institutions in catalyzing and sustaining the changes needed to support this participation.  Findings from this study will contribute to efforts to close undergraduate research participation gaps and guide transformation efforts in undergraduate education. 

To achieve a cohesive curriculum that initiates students into a culture of inquiry and research in the discipline, departments will use a backward design approach to develop scaffolded, research-rich courses and assignments that build in deliberate ways to guide students to greater independence and ownership of their learning. Two overarching research questions will be examined: (1) What effect do student characteristics (e.g., pre-existing academic preparation, current course performance) have on student-learning experiences and outcomes in a scaffolded inquiry-driven curriculum? (2) How do different departmental approaches and distinct disciplinary cultures impact the integration of the components and outcomes of undergraduate research into the curriculum?  A mixed-methods approach will be used to address these questions, including surveys, focus groups with students and faculty, observations and interviews with faculty and team consultants, annual progress reports, and in-depth site visits.  A novel aspect of this project will be the development of both standardized and experimental questions on the National Survey of Student Engagement and the Faculty Survey of Student Engagement.  These surveys will allow for comparison of project institutions with national results.  The theory of change model that develops from this project will allow a broad and diverse range of institutional types and departments/disciplines to assess their readiness for research-scaffolded curricula and provide key insights into the effects of such curricular transformation on student achievement and organizational and cultural change.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Undergraduate research is a high-impact practice that benefits students across demographic groups and disciplines. This longitudinal study, led by the Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) (http://www.cur.org), is described as the CUR Transformations project. The goal of the project was to assist departments in creating more research-rich curricula. This project aimed to provide more equitable access to the benefits of undergraduate research for all students by guiding academic departments through a comprehensive, multi-year process of integrating and scaffolding undergraduate research skills and practices throughout the curriculum. Over a six-year period, we worked intensively with 12 institutions and 24 departments (two departments at each institution) in the fields of biology, chemistry, psychology, and physics. Diverse institutional types are represented in our project: a mix of public and private; large and small; Carnegie classifications; racial and ethnic demographics, including Historically Black Colleges & Universities and Hispanic-serving institutions geographically spread across the country.

The annual cycle of sustained engagement included an in-person collaboration meeting of all project participants, iterative departmental work to create scaffolded curricula, two-to-three-day site visits by consultants coaching each department, and data collection and analysis on project and institutional research questions. Our fundamental research on the student, faculty, departmental, institutional, and disciplinary influences on curricular transformation led to profound insights with respect to the essential steps and conditions (i.e., a new theory of change) necessary for the scaffolding of research skills and practices to positively impact student learning and promote deep cultural change. Over a period of three to five years, successful departments progressed from defining their context and vision for change, through engagement and actions to enable change, allowing them to anchor and sustain transformative change. Identification and cultivation of multiple, diverse campus leaders in the change process; frequent assessments of the change process and effective communication and decision-making; and exploitation of synergies between research-rich undergraduate curricula and other department/institutional priorities were hallmarks of successful change journeys.

These findings are detailed in a forthcoming book, Transforming Academic Culture and Curriculum: Integrating and Scaffolding Research Throughout Undergraduate Education https://www.routledge.com/Transforming-Academic-Culture-and-Curriculum-Integrating-and-Scaffolding/Malachowski-Ambos-Karukstis-Kinzie-Osborn/p/book/9781032581675. Scheduled for publication in early 2024, the volume addresses the call to expand experiential learning opportunities for all undergraduate students. Drawing from lessons learned from the efforts of departments, faculty, and administrators involved in the CUR Transformations project, the book spans both theory and practice for academic departments -- and by extension, institutions -- to transform undergraduate education to increase student success in a relatively short (several year) timespan. A practical tool kit of strategic approaches, practices, and policies that teams used in their change work is included. Our publication is timely, as departments and institutions strive to bridge research and teaching in cost-effective and sustainable ways and provide more students with high-impact experiential learning, against a backdrop of seemingly unremitting challenges (e.g., fiscal shortfalls, demographic shifts, pandemic effects). The work and lessons learned are particularly relevant to the equity imperative in higher education in that they expose more students to research-rich experiences. Although the focus of the project was on STEM disciplines, each of the participating campuses included an institutional leadership team whose goals included leveraging the successes and lessons-learned from the participating departments and scaling these across other departments at the institution. As such, the research findings and lessons learned broadly apply for all academic disciplines. 

Broader Impacts

This project has significant impacts beyond the 12 institutions, their 24 participating departments, and the thousands of students that they teach. In addition to the book referenced above, by the end of the project, participants had authored close to 30 peer-reviewed publications, and delivered over 130 presentations at national, regional, and campus conferences. These dissemination efforts showcase diverse dimensions of STEM curricular and associated culture change transformation and effective professional development. Of the NSF Broader Impacts (BI) criteria, one overarching theme -- improved STEM education and educator development -- is a primary project outcome. First, effective STEM professional development is built on sustained coaching paired with action research program development and subsequent dissemination of research results. Second, nested leadership that includes faculty, student, and administrator voices is essential. Two other linked BI criteria -- full participation of underrepresented groups and development of STEM workforce -- also figure strongly in project outcomes. Curricular scaffolding promotes equity for student success, as it supports and connects learners throughout degree programs. The faculty engagement in the scaffolding process also supports faculty equity. In particular, the project focused on ensuring that faculty members are appropriately credited for their teaching and mentoring and through leadership opportunities for non-tenure track and/or faculty with substantial teaching responsibilities, as well as engagement of graduate students and post-doctoral scholars.
